awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO:   Collaborative Research:  Seizure control through state-specific manipulation of cell assemblies
awd_abstract_narration:
How activity of individual brain neurons results in the emergence, spread, and eventual termination of seizures is a basic and unsolved issue. Extensive research has examined brain activity during seizures using invasive and non-invasive tools, but there is a gap in our understanding of the cellular-level basis of large-scale phenomena such as seizures. Here, Dr. Sarah F. Muldoon (University at Buffalo, SUNY) and Dr. Ethan M. Goldberg (The Children's Hospital of Philadelphia and The University of Pennsylvania) use methods for recording neural activity from multiple single neurons in mice, as well as methods for recording large-scale neuroelectric activity (EEG), to identify groups of neurons whose activity is associated with time-evolving features of seizures. This project combines newly developed theoretical and computational neuroscience approaches with state-of-the art experimental techniques for imaging and manipulating brain activity. It evaluates a novel hypothesis that transitions to seizure onset and between seizure sub-states represent changes in the activity of small, identifiable clusters of neurons, and that such clusters can be identified and manipulated to modulate seizures. This multidisciplinary collaborative approach is expected to produce novel insights into the mechanisms of seizure generation and propagation, inform novel treatments for epilepsy, and provide a framework generalizable to larger efforts to link data related to changes in brain state across scales.

Recent work suggests a fine-grained and evolving heterogeneity in individual neuronal dynamics during seizures. However, relatively little is known about the relationship between single neuron activity and large-scale seizure dynamics. Here, we combine multilayer network theory with two-photon calcium imaging in an experimental in vivo epilepsy model to identify functional cell assemblies (small groups of neurons with similar, functionally-relevant activity patterns) associated with transition to and between seizure states. We characterize the ability of defined subsets GABAergic inhibitory interneurons to impact cell assembly dynamics, using optogenetics to manipulate interneurons to interrupt transition to seizure. The overall goal of this proposal is to develop a means for rapid detection of spatially- and functionally-defined neuronal assemblies associated with these sub-state transitions so as to predict and manipulate such transitions. The results will provide the first large-scale imaging data on the cellular architecture of epileptic seizures in vivo as well as a set of novel tools for the analysis of such data. This work will lead to the development of neural control strategies designed to specifically target subpopulations of neurons that have been functionally identified as key elements in driving epileptic dynamics.

This project is funded by Integrative Strategies for Understanding Neural and Cognitive Systems (NSF-NCS), a multidisciplinary program jointly supported by the Directorates for Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE), Education and Human Resources (EHR), Engineering (ENG), and Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences (SBE).

por.por_cntn:
Epilepsy constitutes a spectrum of disorders characterized by the presence of recurrent seizures, which are paroxysmal electrical discharges in the brain. As one-third of patients remain treatment resistant, the development of alternative methods to suppress and/or modify epileptic activity are essential. How complex circuit-level phenomena such as epileptic seizures emerge from the activity of individual neurons, and how seizures propagate and terminate, are fundamental, yet unsolved, questions. We undertook a multi-disciplinary, collaborative research proposal to investigate the dynamic, cellular architecture of seizures in an experimental model system using in vivo two-photon calcium imaging combined with multi-scale network analysis.

In this project, we proposed the use of two-photon calcium imaging in vivo (2P imaging) to identify functional cell assemblies (small groups of neurons with similar, functionally-relevant activity patterns) associated with the transition to and between seizure states, by applying multi-scale network analysis driven by state-of-the-art cellular-resolution neuroimaging data. The main hypothesis of the proposal was that the transition to seizure onset and between seizure sub-states represents large-scale shifts in functional network architecture, biased by the activity of small, identifiable clusters of neurons (cell assemblies), and that such assemblies could be identified and manipulated to modulate seizures.

The overall goals of this project were therefore: (1) To develop a means to image seizures in awake, behaving experimental animals; (2) To develop algorithms for rapid detection of spatially and functionally defined neuronal assemblies from 2P imaging data, and, ultimately; (3) To predict seizure onset and facilitate targeted manipulations to interrupt or prevent seizure generation and/or propagation.  

 

Experimental Results:  

We succeeded in collection of a calcium imaging data set containing baseline activity, the transition to a seizure, and the seizure event in a mouse model of Dravet syndrome (a severe childhood-onset epilepsy) in mice in which defined subsets of GABAergic inhibitory interneurons were labeled and tracked across time.

We discovered that a prominent subset of GABAergic inhibitory interneuron, the parvalbumin-expressing fast-spiking interneuron (PV-IN), maintains normal activity levels during seizure initiation in epileptic mice, but instead displays differences in synchronization properties as compared to wild-type controls. While excitatory neuron synchrony increased from baseline to late preictal periods in wild-type mice, we observed a slight decrease in the synchronization of excitatory cells in epileptic mice. However, when examining changes in synchronization within PV-IN activity, we found that there was desynchronization of PV-IN activity between baseline and the preictal state in epileptic mice, with no change in PV-IN synchronization in wildtype mice in response to similar seizure-inducing stimuli. We found that synchrony between PV-INs and putative excitatory neurons was higher in epileptic mice at baseline as compared to wild-type, but did not increase with transition across seizure sub-states; in contrast, PV?IN:excitatory neuron synchrony increased with seizure-promoting stimuli in wild-type control mice. Thus, in the Dravet syndrome epilepsy model mice, we observe multiple differences in synchronization properties during transition to seizure. Excitatory cells do not exhibit an increase in synchronization and PV-INs exhibit a progressive decline in synchronization preceding seizure. This results in decreased synchronization between excitatory and inhibitory populations in epileptic mice immediately before the seizure.

 

Theoretical/Analytical Results: 

We discovered a theoretical ?multilayer resolution limit? that limits the ability of modularity maximization to detect changes in communities in multilayer networks.  This resolution limit has important implications for detecting changes in functional cell assemblies during the transition to seizure.  We therefore developed an algorithm to increase sensitivity to detecting changes in communities in temporal networks and minimize the effects of the multilayer resolution limit by updating community detection parameters based on self-similarity meta data between temporal layers.

To better analyze neuroimaging data, we also developed a novel method using persistent homology (topological data analysis)  to localize cells in biomedical images using 0-dimensional and 1-dimensional homology of filtered images.

When attempting to apply dynamic community detection (DCD) algorithms to our imaging data, we discovered that existing algorithms performed poorly in temporal carryover of communities between windows of data.  We defined a new method of interlayer coupling called "skeleton coupling" that is based on static community detection and the presence of simplicial complexes within the community structure.  We showed that Infomap+skeleton coupling is superior in handling temporal carryover and correctly identifying singleton communities in the data. We therefore recommend this combination of coupling and DCD for data in which the transient presence of communities is expected (such as in our seizure data).

 

Broader Impacts:

This work will have broader impacts in the fields of neuroscience, epilepsy, neurology, and network theory.  The results have been presented at interdisciplinary conferences (e.g. SfN, AES, NERCCS) and outreach events. The project has also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students with backgrounds in neuroscience, mathematics, and computational data sciences.  We have published 5 papers and 2 additional drafts are currently under preparation.  All associated software packages will also be made publicly available upon publication.
